conclusion: To determine the motion direction of the particle from 2 to 3 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The vertical axis represents velocity v (measured in meters per second, m/s).
The horizontal axis represents time t (measured in seconds, s).
A positive velocity indicates motion in the positive direction.
A negative velocity indicates motion in the negative direction.
At t = 2 seconds, the velocity is 0.
At t = 3 seconds, the velocity is -2 m/s.

premise: From t = 2 seconds to t = 3 seconds, the velocity transitions from 0 to -2 m/s.
conclusion: A negative velocity indicates that the particle is moving in the negative direction.
The defined positive direction is typically associated with positive velocity values.

premise: Since the velocity is negative (moving from 0 to -2 m/s), the particle is moving in the opposite direction to the defined positive direction.
conclusion: The motion direction of the particle from 2 to 3 seconds is opposite to the defined positive direction.
